#Text=Become a Guide Dog Trainer
#Text=Guide dog trainers perform their job because they have a passion for animals and helping others .
#Text=The level of training to become a guide dog trainer is high and the compensation is often low .
#Text=A trainer is required to work with a puppy for approximately one year , then hand the trained dog over to a person in need of its services .
#Text=The separation can be painful for the trainer , but knowing their training is helping a blind person gain independence can be very rewarding .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Gaining Experience
#Text=Complete a college degree .
#Text=Many places that hire guide dog trainers require a college degree of some sort .
#Text=Consider completing a degree in zoology .
#Text=Although it is not dog training specifically , it will help you understand the anatomical , biological and physiological side of animals .
#Text=It will also give you an edge over the competition when applying for a dog training position .
#Text=A college degree is not a prerequisite to all programs .
#Text=Check with the agency you want to work for .
#Text=Some workplaces will sponsor an apprenticeship for you to become trainer , but you need a four year college degree .
#Text=Volunteer at an animal shelter .
#Text=As a guide dog trainer , you must be able to work with people and dogs , since you are training dogs to interact appropriately with people .
#Text=A shelter will give you many opportunities to work with both .
#Text=Duties might be :
#Text=Answer incoming calls .
#Text=Perform clerical work for adoptions .
#Text=Help scared dogs adjust to a new environment .
#Text=Match pets with new owners .

#Text=Volunteer at an animal hospital . Volunteering at an animal hospital may be less hands-on than at a shelter , because animals are being treated for injuries and illness , but it will help feed your passion for dogs .
#Text=Research what hospitals in your area take volunteers .
#Text=Some may be more hands-on than others and require you to complete an application .
#Text=Expect to do things like cleaning out kennels and checking in patients .
#Text=Volunteerism looks good to an employer on an application , because it shows you are passionate enough about the field to work for free .
#Text=Seek employment working with dogs directly .
#Text=Get a job working with dogs , even if it 's just at your local pet store .
#Text=It will give you experience and help you learn how dogs ' minds operate .
#Text=Work as a dog sitter or dog walker .
#Text=They are both in high demand , since people increasingly think of their dogs as family members .
#Text=Anything to get you working around dogs !
#Text=Apply for a job at a guide dog school .
#Text=After gaining some experience working with or around animals , apply for a position at a guide dog school .
#Text=Work your way up to become a trainer by starting in a different position , like a kennel assistant or attendant .
#Text=They help feed , bathe and walk dogs and are great ways to start .
#Text=You have a better chance at getting an interview for an apprenticeship if you are already working for the school .
#Text=Getting an Apprenticeship
#Text=Apply for an apprenticeship .
#Text=On-the-job training programs for guide dog trainers are offered to all qualified applicants .
#Text=Some jobs want you to have experience working with dogs and some are more concerned with finding the right type of person .
#Text=Look at job postings at companies that train service dogs .
#Text=Many will have a dedicated employment page on their website .
#Text=Complete an apprenticeship program .
#Text=An apprenticeship can take anywhere from two to four years to complete , depending upon the company and its requirements .
#Text=You must be in good physical shape to complete the program , since it requires a lot of physical agility and stamina .
#Text=Eat healthy and exercise regularly .
#Text=Plus , be prepared to assist with teaching dogs and take on ever increasing responsibilities working under a master trainer .
#Text=Turn in applications for a position as a guide dog trainer .
#Text=If you 're not offered a job at the place you apprenticed at , you will be qualified to apply for positions after you complete it .
#Text=Depending upon the company you apply at , you may have to pass a written test they issue to screen for the best candidates .
#Text=It may take several tries to get a job , as the competition is tough .
#Text=Going to Guide Dog Trainer School
#Text=Investigate a trainer school thoroughly .
#Text=Most guide dog trainers are self-taught through extensive experience working with dogs or they completed an apprenticeship program , but there are a handful of schools .
#Text=Do your homework before you commit .
#Text=Some things a good school should offer are :
#Text=The history of dog training starting from the late 19th century .
#Text=Animal learning including positive and negative reinforcement , and human versus dog learning .
#Text=Dog behavior , including breed temperaments and social cues .
#Text=How to design classes to best teach owners and dogs interaction skills .
#Text=Apply to a school that offers science-based programs .
#Text=Guide dog trainers know through science how dogs operate and think .
#Text=Apply to a school that offers an Associate of Science , Bachelor of Science or Master of Science degree if you can .
#Text=Some schools may not offer degree plans , but can still educate on how to be a good trainer .
#Text=Make sure they offer classes on biology and other life sciences .
#Text=Get certified through CCPDT .
#Text=The Certification Council for Professional Dog Trainers is the only widely recognized dog trainer certification .
#Text=This certification shows your professionalism and that you are familiar with the most current training techniques .
#Text=To get certified , you need to :
#Text=Complete at least 300 hours of training experience from the past three years .
#Text=Provide a signed reference from a veterinarian or CCPDT certificate .
#Text=Agree to the CCPDT code of ethics .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Attend as many workshops as you can on dog training .
#Text=Methods and techniques are constantly changing , oftentimes for the better .
#Text=Try to remain current on this information .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Before learning how to become a guide dog trainer , make sure you are capable of giving up an animal you have bonded with .
#Text=This can be difficult for many people .
